Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of RNA-Processing Protein Dynamics with Simultaneous High-Resolution Optical Traps and Single-Molecule Fluorescence

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Investigation of RNA-processing protein dynamics with simultaneous high-resolution optical traps and single-molecule fluorescence

In this project, the PI will develop optical methods that will enable direct observation in real-time of the activity of protein machines that are involved in processing RNA. RNA is one of the essential carriers of cell information, and its production and degradation are tightly controlled by RNA protein interactions associated with protein machines. The overall goal of this project is to investigate how both the cooperation and competition between different molecular machines lead to the careful regulation of information in the cell. The techniques developed in this project will apply beyond the protein machines involved in RNA processing to include a broad assortment of complex protein systems. This project will leverage optical methods development and the strong art and science connection at Michigan State University to develop an education and outreach program centered on hands-on interactions with biophysical science at the individual cell and RNA molecule level. The PI will create a video game lab experience aimed at students and the public.

This project will investigate RNA-processing protein dynamics of single proteins and larger protein machine assemblies by developing and applying high-resolution, multi-modal single molecule techniques. Specifically, the PI will investigate the yeast nuclear RNA helicase Mtr4p and the associated TRAMP protein complex. Mtr4p and TRAMP have emerged as key players in nuclear RNA surveillance and processing in part via precise modification of RNA for degradation by the exosome. How these machines coordinate or compete to achieve function is controversial in large part due to their highly dynamic, multi-degree of freedom interactions on the scale of only 5-10 nucleotides of RNA. The PI will address the fundamental questions regarding how Mtr4p and TRAMP function using single-molecule and high resolution optical tweezers and fluorescence. Advanced techniques combining high-resolution optical trapping and multi-color fluorescence will apply broadly across all biophysical molecular dynamics investigations towards the emerging need for tools to investigate protein-nucleic acid interactions beyond the individual molecule scale towards multi-protein, multi-degree of freedom complex systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded investigations of the processing of RNA by protein molecular machines using methods that enabled us to directly watch individual molecules do their jobs. Molecules like RNA and DNA are long polymer strands containing information needed to operate a living cell. Many protein machines are needed to process the information in these strands. DNA processing machines have been studied in detail previously but RNA processing machines less so. In part this is because RNA molecules differ from DNA in that as transient information carriers, they tend to be much shorter (hundreds vs >millions bases long), they are single stranded and thus fold up into more complex structures, and they are actively monitored, processed and destroyed by the cell. The RNA processing machines often work on smaller scales in very specific ways on a large variety of specific RNA structures. Here we looked at a very fundamental RNA helicase, called Mtr4, whose job is to unwind short sections of zipped up double stranded RNA. It does this while working with other proteins to perform a variety of crucial jobs inside the cell including helping to mark some RNA molecules for preservation but conversely, also assisting the RNA ‘garbage disposal’ (the exosome) in destroying others. We developed single molecule methods – methods whereby we could experimentally observe individual proteins in action doing their RNA processing jobs – so that we could see clearly how this RNA helicase unwinds RNA. It is not easy to make these observations, because these kinds of RNA helicases move slowly, take very small steps – only nanometers at a time, and don’t move very far. We use laser tweezers to grab onto and watch these molecules and we had to make our tweezers even more stable and precise than ever before. We then found that the RNA helicase worked in some ways like their DNA motor counterparts, in that one of them could unwind RNA by steadily marching ahead, step by step, unwinding a long sequence. This would allow it to lead the way for the exosome as a long strand of unwanted RNA is chopped to pieces. But it also showed great specificity and sensitivity for the context of its work, and the structure of the RNA – in contrast to DNA helicases – for example, the helicase motor stops itself when the unwinding job is done. These investigations help us to understand how our cells use protein machines to process RNA information within the cell.

Our advancements in methods to precisely observe individual molecules also led to complementary advances in related biophysical science including investigations of how the nucleic acid (RNA and DNA strands) and protein parts are structured. We were able to watch individual DNA and protein structures unfold and refold while gently pulling on them with the laser tweezers. Our ‘gentleness’ combined with high measurement resolution allowed us to observe the entire process of unfolding and folding all at once in conditions much closer to ‘normal’ for the molecules than previously. This allowed us a clear view of how these structures get formed in the cell. These methods advances were shared with other biophysical researchers and should help with many fundamental investigations into how the molecules of life work.

We developed an outreach program inviting the general public into our lab to experience for themselves using our laser tweezers microscopes to pull on individual strands of DNA and grab swimming cells. The instruments were modified for a safe and accessible experience. Children to seniors participated. Children in particular enjoyed the ‘video-game-like’ experience of chasing down cells while operating the laser with a joystick. This event enabled a first-hand experience of the micro- and nano-scale world of biology and physics and made real the activities supported by this grant for the public. Events like this will continue and expand in the future.
